p: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is an enveloped, positive strand RNA virus member of the genus Hepacivirus of the Flaviviridae family. The HCV genome consists of an RNA molecule of approximately 9.6 kb in size containing a single open reading frame flanked by structured 5′ and 3′ un-translated regions. An internal ribosome entry site directs the translation of a polyprotein precursor that is cleaved by cellular and viral proteases into 10 proteins (core, E1, E2, p7, NS2, NS3, NS4a, NS4b, NS5a, and NS5B) (reviewed in reference [1]). Human HCV infection causes chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, and is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma [2]. It is estimated that 180 million people worldwide are infected with HCV [3] and given the chronic nature of the infection it is expected that the number of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma will increase in the coming years.
